sub_title: Senior lecturer at University of Amsterdam
summary:
Yves works as senior lecturer at the Department of Human Geography, Planning and International Development Studies at the University of Amsterdam. He is trained in rural development sociology and social anthropology. He obtained his PhD at Wageningen University in 2013 and has conducted extensive anthropological fieldwork and action research in Sub-Saharan Africa since 2002. His research and teaching interests involve rural transformation processes, with a particular focus on land rights and food systems. He has studied land reform and public-private partnerships in various settings, with a focus on the brokering roles of powerful elites such as ‘white’ nature conservationists, value chain actors and traditional leaders as well as small-scale farmers striving for autonomous production. Taking a people-centered approach, he analyses how state- and private sector models are reworked locally through actors’ organizing practices. In this process, authority, knowledge and sovereignty are contested at multiple sites and scale levels. Outcomes are represented in new territorial configurations and land rights, public authority and counter-veiling discourses such as ‘inclusive growth’ and ‘food sovereignty’. Recently, he has expanded his research to rural – urban linkages and cities in Africa and Southern Europe as sites of alternative food movements and collective place-making strategies aimed at reclaiming urban commons. Methodologically, he aims to contribute to the ‘anthropology of brokerage’ and making value chain collaborations more socially-just through action research that appreciates farmers’ local knowledge. He enjoys teaching critical development theory and aims to contribute to developing practical approaches to decolonizing the university curriculum. He has taught and currently teaches a broad range of classes at Master's and Bachelor's levels, ranging from introductory courses in International Development Studies, in-depth theoretical courses to research methodologies and professional and academic skills. 
For publication list see: https://www.researchgate.net/profile/Yves_Van_Leynseele

profile_positions.description: This project examines whether and how value chain collaboration involving tree-crop farmers in Ghana (cocoa and oil palm) and South Africa (macadamia and avocado) can be made more equitable and inclusive. As postdoctoral researcher I conduct primary research and facilitate joint learning through a Learning Platform approach that was developed with international and local partners and through action research with smallholder producers.  See: https://inclusivevcc.wordpress.com/
